g.text: ects will be slight, and this could be the reason that the average friction
forces become lower with the increase in depth of the defects, when
Using an EAMpotential, MDsimulations have been carried out to study the e
erent depths, widths, orientations and shapes on friction behaviors during
nanoscale sliding contacts. The inﬂuence of subsurface defects on the substrate is also discussed.
Under the conditions and material used in this paper, some conclusions are drawn, as follows:
(1) Compared with a smooth surface, textured surfaces can reduce friction forces e
In addition, the textured surfaces with a higher depth and smaller width lead to lower average
(2) For the texture surfaces with the orientations of 0
, the average friction forces are higher
produces the lowest average friction force.
ects of texture shape on friction behaviors are slight compared with the e
width and orientation, and the v-shape shows a lower average friction force.
(4) The nanoscale ball defects in the substrate make the sliding process unstable. In this paper, when
the depth of the ball defects is
3.615 nm, the inﬂuence of defects on the average friction force
is the greatest. When the depth is greater than 3.615 nm, the average friction forces decrease with
the increase in depth, and they tend to be close to that of a perfect substrate.
Conceptualization, R.T.; methodology, R.T., Z.Q., Y.Z. and B.H.; software, Z.Q. and
B.H.; formal analysis, R.T. and Z.Q.; investigation, R.T., Z.Q. and Y.Z.; writing—original draft preparation, Z.Q.;
writing—review and editing, R.T.; visualization, Z.Q.; supervision, R.T.; project administration, R.T. and G.L.;
This research was funded by National Natural Science Foundation of China, grant number 51675429,
Key Project of National Natural Science Foundation of China, grant number 51535009, the Fundamental Research
Funds for the Central Universities, grant number 31020190503004, and the 111 Project, grant number B13044.
R.T. would like to thank the Top International University Visiting Programfor Outstanding
Young Scholars of Northwestern Polytechnical University.
The authors declare no conﬂict of interest. The funders had no role in the design of the
study; in the collection, analyses, or interpretation of data; in the writing of the manuscript, or in the decision to
